com.sonyericsson.inject
Class DuctTape

java.lang.Object
  com.sonyericsson.inject.DuctTape

public class DuctTape
extends Object

A framework for dependency injection and automatic instantiation of required implementations.

Topics covered here:

  1. Introduction
  2. Injected Fields
  3. Array Injection
  4. Factory Objects
  5. Context Awareness
  6. View Support
  7. Debug Output

Introduction

Automatic dependency injection in Java is the concept of letting objects know the presence of each other through a registration framework, and never hard code which object references another anywhere. The benefits in an object oriented environment like Java is complete flexibility of the system configuration and the promotion of modularity. Simply put, using dependency injection each logical functionality in your system should be an interface, and the implementation is then smaller or larger modules that implements one or more interfaces. The injection framework ties it all together and makes the implementation completely independent on how you have implemented the interfaces.

The aim with this class is to provide a very easy and efficient way to use dependency injection, and the name tries to reflect that. In essence you just take all your objects and wrap them in duct tape: 

 DuctTape dt = new DuctTape();
 
 dt.add(anObject);
 dt.add(anotherObject);
 dt.add(yetAnotherObject);
 
 // Inject references to requested types
 dt.apply();

In case your setup changes, e.g. a new window was created and you want to stick it to the existing object mesh, you simply add the object and apply some more tape: 

 dt.add(oneMoreObject);
 dt.apply();

The same procedure can be applied regardless weather objects were removed, added or both.

Injected Fields

To make values become injected into an object the class must fist be marked as and injection target by implementing the Gluey interface. Once that is in place all fields of the class can be marked as injection targets by adding the Glue annotation. 

 class MyClass implements Gluey {
 
     @Glue
     private SuperService mTheService;
 
     @Glue
     private CheeseManager mManager;
 
 }

By default an object requires something to be available to inject into all of its fields marked with Glue. However, by adding the OPTIONAL tag to the Glue annotation the framework is told that it is OK not to inject anything into that field. 

 import static com.sonyericsson.inject.DuctTape.OPTIONAL;
 ...
 
 @Glue(OPTIONAL)
 private SomeClass mObject;

This is an example of using a built-in tag on with the Glue annotation, but you can also use custom tags. These tags are used to select only those objects which have previously been tagged with at least on of the given tags, e.g. 

 // Define tag constant instead of using raw integers
 public static final MY_TAG = DuctTape.MIN_TAG;
 ...
 
 // Require the injected object to be tagged
 @Glue(MY_TAG)
 private SomeClass mObject;
 ...
 
 // Add and tag the object
 dt = new DuctTape();
 dt.add(myObject, MY_TAG);

It is also possible to supply several tags with the Glue annotation. These can be a mix of built-in tags and custom tags. 

 @Glue({
         OPTIONAL, MY_FIRST_TAG, MY_SECOND_TAG
 })
 private SomeClass mObject;

In this case the injected object is required to be tagged with either MY_FIRST_TAG or MY_SECOND_TAG, and the field is allowed to be injected with null in case there is no matching object.

Array Injection

Normally an injected field represents a single reference or value. When several objects that could be injected has been found this would cause an GluingException. However, by declaring the field as an array it will instead receive all of the matching objects. 

 // This causes an exception when there are several
 // object of SomeClass type.
 private SomeClass mObject;
 
 // This works well with both one and many objects of
 // the SomeClass type.
 private SomeClass[] mObjects;

It is also possible to inject into primitive arrays this way. Object of the corresponding type will then be collected and converted into a primitive array before injection. 

 private int[] mValues;
 ...
 
 dt.add(new Integer(123));
 dt.add(new Integer(45));
 dt.add(67);
 
 // This will inject int[]{123, 45, 67} into mValues
 dt.apply();

However, since arrays are also objects this can sometimes lead to ambiguous situations where it is not possible to know if the intention was to inject one of the added arrays or to inject an array of matching objects. In these cases apply() will throw an GluingException informing about the situation. 

 private String[] mMessages;
 ...
 
 String[] msgs = new String[] {
         "first", "second"
 };
 ...
 
 dt.add((Object)msgs);
 dt.add("third");
 dt.add("fourth");
 
 dt.apply(); // will throw an exception

Normally this case is easily avoided by tagging the array and array injections, since adding and injecting untagged arrays are usually a sign of bad design anyhow.

Factory Objects

When adding a Class object it will be treated in a special manner. It will not be directly available for injection, instead it is used to instantiate an object when there is a field compatible with its type, which is useful when resources should only be allocated when the object is in use. The creation will however only be done when the following criteria hold:

  • The injection is not tagged with OPTIONAL.
  • All injections in the object that is about to be constructed can be performed successfully.

The latter bullet might require other Class objects to be investigated. Circular references in these cases are allowed and resolved by analyzing the big picture.

It is possible to tag Class objects just as ordinary added objects. When that is done the constructed object will have the same tag-set as its class, and only be injected where matched by the injection criteria.

Normally a factory creates a new instance of the object for each injection. This behavior can however be changed by making the class implementing the Singleton interface. That tells the framework that the same object instance should be used for all injections.

Context Awareness

This class was designed with Android as primary target and has support for automatically extracting resources and services from an application context. This means that if you add an Context all fields that have any of the types AccountManager, ActivityManager, AlarmManager, KeyguardManager, NotificationManager, SearchManager, UiModeManager, WallpaperManager, DevicePolicyManager, ContentResolver, ApplicationInfo, PackageManager, AssetManager, Resources, XmlResourceParser, SensorManager, LocationManager, AudioManager, ConnectivityManager, WifiManager, DropBoxManager, Looper, PowerManager, Vibrator, TelephonyManager, ClipboardManager, LayoutInflater, WindowManager or AccessibilityManager will be injected with whatever the context gives us.

The resources can be injected by simply stating the resource ID as tag on the injection: 

 @Glue(R.integer.timeout)
 int mTimeout;

This also works on array resources.

View Support

In addition to built in support for application contexts there is also support for extracting and inflating views. This is done by specifying the view or layout ID as injection tag and giving a sub-class of View as field type. The following steps will then be taken in the attempt to find a suitable object to inject:

  1. All added views are scanned for the given ID.
  2. If an Activity were added its content view is scanned for the given ID.
  3. If an Context of any kind were added it is used to try to inflate the layout with the given ID.

Note that unless the resulting view is of a type that can be cast to the field where it is injected the search for an injectable object is considered to have failed.

Debug Output

Apart from the standard toString() and toShortString() that supplies the developer with textual debug information, there is also the toDotString() method which returns a graph description of the current object mesh. The graph is returned in the DOT language and is primarily intended to be run through a graph generator such as the Graphviz Gvedit. A typical result might look like this:

Field Detail

MIN_TAG

public static final int MIN_TAG
The minimum value of a tag set on an object. An object may be tagged with any integer equal to or between this value and MAX_TAG.

It is recommended to use this constant as base for an enumeration of constants representing tags in an application.

See Also:
MAX_TAG, Constant Field Values

MAX_TAG

public static final int MAX_TAG
The maximum value of a tag set on an object. An object may be tagged with any integer equal to or between MIN_TAG and this value.

See Also:
MIN_TAG, Constant Field Values

OPTIONAL

public static final int OPTIONAL
Tag that allows a field to be injected with null when there is nothing to inject. It can only be used together with Glue. Note that when this tag is present on an injection there will be no attempts made to use added classes to instantiate objects for this field.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

ORDERED

public static final int ORDERED
Tag that makes injected references become sorted by dependency. It can only be used together with Glue and makes sure that objects that other objects depend on are always present before the objects that are dependent on them. Note that it does only affect fields of with an array type.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

DuctTape

public DuctTape()
Creates an empty and robust instance without any connection to the Android system. This is useful for non-Android specific implementations.

add

public final void add(Iterable<?> objs)
Convenience method to add a sequence of objects. Use this when adding objects to e.g. a collection, set or other structure that supports the Iterable interface.

Parameters:
objs - An object enumerating the objects to be added.
See Also:
remove(Iterable objs), add(Object, int[])

add

public final void add(Object obj,
                      int[] tags)

Adds an object to the object mesh and tags it with the given tags. In case the object has already been added the given tags are appended to the tags already present on the object.

Class objects are treated specially in the sense that they are not directly added, but instead the object they represent is created on-demand when another object requires its type. These on-demand objects are persistent as long as the class object is not removed from the mesh (the removal is however not permanent until a call to apply() is made).

Parameters:
obj - The object to add to the list of objects to be glued.
tags - Tags to be set on the object, or null in case the object should be added without any tags.
See Also:
remove(Object), add(Object), add(Object[]), add(Object, int)

remove

public final void remove(Object obj)
Removes an object from the mesh. In case the object is a Class which has been used to create an object, that object is also removed (that operation is however postponed until the next call to apply() in case the removal is reverted).

This method does nothing when the given object is not present in the mesh.

Parameters:
obj - The object to remove.
See Also:
add(Object, int[]), remove(int), remove(Object), remove(Object[]), remove(Iterable)

remove

public final void remove(Object[] objs)
Convenience method to remove an array of objects.

Parameters:
objs - The objects to remove.

remove

public final void remove(Iterable<?> objs)
Convenience method to remove a sequence of objects. Use this when removing objects in a e.g. a collection, set or other structure that supports the Iterable interface.

Parameters:
objs - An object enumerating the objects to be removed. Objects not in the mesh are ignored.

remove

public final void remove(int[] tags)
Removes objects with any of the given tags. Note that no distinction is made between Class objects and regular objects here (objects automatically created from Class objects are however removed together with the class).

Parameters:
tags - Tags on objects to remove. An object matches when any of these tags are set on the object.
See Also:
remove(int), remove(Object)

remove

public final void remove(int tag)
Convenience method to remove all objects with the given tag.

Parameters:
tag - Tag on objects to remove.
See Also:
remove(int[]), remove(Object)

remove

public final void remove(Object obj,
                         int tag)
Removes a tag from the given object. In case the object is a Class which has already constructed an object in a previous call to apply() that object's tags will be updated to match those of the constructing Class.

This method does nothing when the given object is not a part of the list of objects to be to be glued together.

Parameters:
obj - Object on which to remove the tag.
tag - The tag to remove.

clear

public final void clear()
Resets this instance to the same state as it had when it was first constructed. This method is mainly intended as a way to recycle instances.

isRobust

public final boolean isRobust()
Gives the current status of the glued object mesh. Just after apply() has been executed the mesh is always robust, but adding and removing objects usually changes that.

Note that this method does not scan any objects, why changes made directly to injected fields will not be detected (and are not recommended anyhow).

Returns:
true when all objects has been properly injected, false when some changes has been made and apply() has not yet been called.

apply

public final void apply()
                 throws GluingException
Calculates the robust state of the object mesh and injects values in all tagged fields. This method does nothing when there are no objects to glue together or the object mesh is already robust.

Throws:
GluingException - when an injection fails either because of problems outside of this method, e.g. in object constructors, or because it was not possible to come to a conclusion on what to inject into a specific field.
See Also:
isRobust()

toShortString

public final String toShortString()
Creates a short text describing the current status.

Returns:
A single line status text.
See Also:
toString(), toDotString()

toDotString

public final String toDotString()
Creates a graph representation of the current object relations. The graph is described using the DOT language.

Note that the output will always reflect the current contents of the object fields and does not necessarily correspond to a robust object mesh (is case the mesh is not robust because of operations on the DuctTape instance this fact is added as a warning message to the graph).

In case the output is to be printed somewhere where newlines are not allowed or appropriate you can use the following snippet to get the output as a single compact line: 

 String compact = dt.toDot.replaceAll("\t|\n| ", "");

Returns:
An indented multi-line representation of the current object relations as a graph.
See Also:
toShortString(), toString()

toString

public final String toString()
Creates a plain-text representation of the current object relations. The be somewhat compact, and easy to navigate and interpret, the output assumes that the reader is somewhat familiar with the code from which it originates (since it omits details about the injections that can easily be seen in the code).

Note that the output will always reflect the current contents of the object fields and does not necessarily correspond to a robust object mesh (is case the mesh is not robust because of operations on the DuctTape instance this fact is indicated in the beginning of the output).

In case the output is to be printed somewhere where newlines are not allowed or appropriate you can use the following snippet to get the output as a single compact line: 

 String compact = dt.toString().replaceAll("\t|\n| ", "");

Overrides:
toString in class Object
Returns:
An indented multi-line representation of the current object relations as plain-text.
See Also:
toShortString(), toDotString()
